Rosalind - Expected Number of Restriction Sites

22 Jan 2016

Another problem based purely on probability and expected values.

Analysis

The question asks us to find the expected number of times we see a string $s$ as a substring of a string of length $n$ constructed with a given GC-content.

We assign a indicator random variable $I_i$ equal to $1$ if we see the string $s$ beginning at the $i^{\text{th}}$ position. Thus, we have to find

This is due to Linearity of Expectation.

The calculations of all $E[I_i]$ values are identical. Once we find the probabilities of getting symbols $G, C, T, A $ from the GC-content, we simply multiply them according the the symbols observed in $s.$

For example, if the GC-content is $0.25$, $P(G) = 0.125, P(C) = 0.125, P(A) = 0.375, P(T) = 0.375.$ Then string AG is constructed with probability $ 0.125 \cdot 0.375.$ Refer to this post to calculate the probabilities above.

Once we have the probability of randomly constructing string $ s $, the expected value of $ I_i$ is simply the expected value of a Bernoulli trial, i.e., there is a certain probability of success and failure. In our case, the success occurs if we randomly construct string $s.$ Let this expected value equal $x.$ Now, since the calculation of all $E[I_i]$ is identical, our answer is $ x \cdot (n - 1).$
